docs.text: []{#lakeriverstreambottom} Concept: lakeriverstreambottom Child of: earthsurface Specimen samples the solid Earth interface with a lake or flowing water body
docs.title: Lake river or stream bottom

docs.text: []{#marinewaterbodybottom} Concept: marinewaterbodybottom Child of: earthsurface Specimen samples the solid Earth interface with marine or brackish water body. Includes benthic boundary layer: the bottom layer of water and the uppermost layer of sediment directly influenced by the overlying water
docs.title: Marine water body bottom

docs.text: []{#subaerialsurfaceenvironment} Concept: subaerialsurfaceenvironment Child of: earthsurface Specimen samples the interface between solid Earth and atmosphere. Sample is collected on the surface, or immediately below surface (zone of bioturbation). Include soil ‘O’ horizon and ‘biomantle’. Soil horizons below surface, or sediment in active deposition (no soil development) is considered part of solid Earth.
docs.title: Subaerial surface environment

docs.text: []{#glacierenvironment} Concept: glacierenvironment Child of: earthenvironment Sample of ice or water from a glacier, ice sheet, ice shelf, iceberg. Does not include various environments adjacent to glacier.
docs.title: Glacier environment

docs.text: []{#subsurfacefluidreservoir} Concept: subsurfacefluidreservoir Child of: earthenvironment Specimen samples fluid that resides in fractures or intergranular porosity in the solid earth.
docs.title: Subsurface fluid reservoir

docs.text: []{#waterbody} Concept: waterbody Child of: earthenvironment specimen samples the hydrosphere
docs.title: Water body

docs.text: []{#marinewaterbody} Concept: marinewaterbody Child of: waterbody specimen samples marine hydrosphere See Also: obo:ENVO_01000686
docs.title: Marine environment

docs.text: []{#terrestrialwaterbody} Concept: terrestrialwaterbody Child of: waterbody specimen samples terrestrial hydrosphere-- lake, other standing water, or a flowing water body (river, stream..) Include saline water in terrestrial evaporite environments.
docs.title: Terrestrial water body

docs.text: []{#extraterrestrialenvironment} Concept: extraterrestrialenvironment Child of: anysampledfeature specimen samples environment outside of solid earth, hydrosphere, or atmosphere.
docs.title: Extraterrestrial environment

docs.text: Namespace: https://w3id.org/isample/vocabulary/specimentype/0.9/specimentypevocabulary History 2022-01-07 SMR Change base URI to https://w3id.org/isample/vocabulary/, setting up resolution using w3id. Make the conceptScheme and ontology. Add Dublin core imports. 2022-03-11 SMR change definitions from rdfs:comment to skos:definition. Minor fixes in definitions. Add skos matches to URIs from other vocabularies. 2022-09-30 SMR per https://github.com/isamplesorg/metadata/issues/109, change specimen to sample in vocabulary names and labels. Add 'Slurry biome aggregation' and 'Bundle biome aggregation' (github issue 110). Rename 'liquid or gas' sample type to 'fluid in container' (github issue 108). Concepts Physical specimen Any aggregation specimen Anthropogenic aggregation Biome aggregation sample Bundle biome aggregation Aggregation Artifact Any biological specimen Biome aggregation sample Bundle biome aggregation Organism part Organism product Whole organism specimen Fluid in container Fossil Other solid object Research product Analytical preparation Experiment product Physical specimen ¶ []{#physicalspecimen} Concept: physicalspecimen top concept in specimen type hierarchy. Represents any physical specimen. Any aggregation specimen ¶ []{#anyaggregation} Concept: anyaggregation Child of: physicalspecimen Sample consists of a bunch of material fragments, not related to the same object (e.g. not a bunch of broken pot sherds that might be reassembled), but taken together representative of the sampled feature. Examples: loose soil, sediment, crushed rock, particulate, bunches of unrelated pot sherd, human production waste, filtrates and residues. The sample requires some kind of container to keep it together. Cores of loosely consolidated material are considered 'piece of solid material' because the internal parts have spatial relationships (e.g. upper part, lower part). Anthropogenic aggregation ¶ []{#anthropogenicaggregation} Concept: anthropogenicaggregation Child of: anyaggregation Aggregation consists of fragments of material produced by human activity, not described individually, and generally not all originating from the same object. Includes pottery in an excavation unit that gets an aggregate description, production waste, production raw-materials, or other residues (broken bits of plaster from an destroyed wall), synthetic powders. Biome aggregation sample ¶ []{#biomeaggregation} Concept: biomeaggregation Child of: anyaggregation biologicalspecimen Specimen is an aggregation of whole or fragmentary parts of multiple organisms, microscopic or megascopic, representative of some site. Bundle biome aggregation ¶ []{#bundlebiomeaggregation} Concept: bundlebiomeaggregation Child of: biomeaggregation An aggregation of whole organisms representative of some biome Aggregation ¶ []{#genericaggregation} Concept: genericaggregation Child of: anyaggregation An aggregate specimen that is not biogenic or composed of anthropogenic material fragments. Examples: loose soil or sediment (e.g. in a bag), rock chips, particulate filtrate or precipitate; rock powders. Artifact ¶ []{#artifact} Concept: artifact Child of: physicalspecimen An object made (manufactured, shaped, modified) by a human being, or precursor hominid. Include a set of pieces belonging originally to a single object and treated as a single specimen. Any biological specimen ¶ []{#biologicalspecimen} Concept: biologicalspecimen Child of: physicalspecimen Specimen for which the sampled feature is one or more living organisms from a particular biome context, megascopic or microscopic Biome aggregation sample ¶ []{#biomeaggregation} Concept: biomeaggregation Child of: anyaggregation biologicalspecimen Specimen is an aggregation of whole or fragmentary parts of multiple organisms, microscopic or megascopic, representative of some site. Bundle biome aggregation ¶ []{#bundlebiomeaggregation} Concept: bundlebiomeaggregation Child of: biomeaggregation An aggregation of whole organisms representative of some biome Organism part ¶ []{#organismpart} Concept: organismpart Child of: biologicalspecimen Part of an organism, e.g. a tissue sample, plant leaf, flower, bird feather. Include internal parts not composed of organic material (e.g. teeth, bone), and hard body parts that are not shed (hoof, horn, tusk, claw). Hair is tricky, include here for now. Does not necessarily imply existance of parent sample. Not fossilized; generally includes organism parts native to deposits of Holocene to Recent age. Organism product ¶ []{#organismproduct} Concept: organismproduct Child of: biologicalspecimen Specimen is a thing produced by some organism, generally not composed of organic material or including biological tissue, e.g. Shell, antler, egg shell, coral skeleton (organic tissue not included), fecal matter, cocoon, web. Consider internal parts not composed of organic material (e.g. teeth, bone) and hard body parts that are not shed (hoof, horn, tusk) to be organism parts. Whole organism specimen ¶ []{#wholeorganism} Concept: wholeorganism Child of: biologicalspecimen Specimen consists of the bodies of one or more entire organisms of the same species, from any kingdom. Note that these are also inherently 'solid object' Fluid in container ¶ []{#fluidincontainer} Concept: fluidincontainer Child of: physicalspecimen Specimen is a container whose contents are liquid, gas, or mixed dominantly fluid phases, that is the actual sample material. Fluid might include minor solid particles. Container typically human made, but also includes natural fluid container, e.g. fluid inclusion in a mineral grain. Includes colloids, foams, gels, suspensions. The sample is the fluid substance; fluid samples collected to analyze the contained biome should be considered 'Biome Aggregation' Fossil ¶ []{#fossil} Concept: fossil Child of: physicalspecimen Specimen is the remains of one or more organisms preserved in rock; includes whole body, body parts (usually bone or shell), and trace fossils. An organism or organism part becomes a fossil when it has undergone some fossilization process that generally entails physical and chemical changes akin to diagenesis in a sedimentary rock. Trace fossils are manifestations of biologic activity preserved in a rock body (typically sedimentary), without included preserved body parts. Other solid object ¶ []{#othersolidobject} Concept: othersolidobject Child of: physicalspecimen Single piece of material not one of the other types, e.g. rock specimen, mineral specimen, core. Ice and permafrost are considered solid materials. Research product ¶ []{#researchproduct} Concept: researchproduct Child of: physicalspecimen Specimen is a product of some research workflow, e.g. a thin section, an XRF pellet, a grain mount, SEM stub, synthetic rock or mineral ... In general there should be a link to a parent specimen from which this was derived. Might be aggregation (e.g. a synthetic material powder) or a solid object. Analytical preparation ¶ []{#analyticalpreparation} Concept: analyticalpreparation Child of: researchproduct Specimen is a product of processing required for some observation procedure, e.g. thin section, XRF bead, SEM stub, rock powder. If identified separately, this should have a ‘parent’ link to the original sample Experiment product ¶ []{#experimentalproduct} Concept: experimentalproduct Child of: researchproduct Specimen is product of an experimental procedure (e.g. synthetic material)
